query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Noi andavam con li diece demoni. 14 Ahi fiera compagnia! ma ne la chiesa 15 coi santi, e in taverna coi ghiottoni.
query.result:
**English:**
13 We went with the ten demons. 14 Ah, fierce company! but in church 15 with the saints, and in the tavern with the gluttons.
**Old English:**
13 We eodon mid ðæm tyn deoflum. 14 Eala, grymlic geferræden! ac on cyrcan 15 mid ðæm halgum, and on ceape mid ðæm gifrum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Pur a la pegola era la mia ’ntesa, 17 per veder de la bolgia ogne contegno 18 e de la gente ch’entro v’era incesa.
query.result:
**English:**
16 My attention was completely focused on the pitch, 17 to see every detail of the bolgia 18 and of the people who were burning inside it.
**Old English:**
16 Þurh ða pic ðær wæs min andgit, 17 for ðan ðe ic wolde ðære byrgene ealle 18 and ða leoda ðe ðær on innan wæron forbærned.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Come i dalfini, quando fanno segno 20 a’ marinar con l’arco de la schiena 21 che s’argomentin di campar lor legno,
22 talor così, ad alleggiar la pena, 23 mostrav’ alcun de’ peccatori ’l dosso 24 e nascondea in men che non balena.
query.result:
**English:**
19 Like dolphins, when they make a sign 20 to the sailors with the arch of their backs 21 that they should try to save their ship,
22 sometimes in the same way, to alleviate their pain, 23 one of the sinners would show his back 24 and hide it again in less time than it takes for lightning to flash.
**Old English:**
19 Swa swa ða delfinas, ðonne hi ðone sælidan 20 mid hrycge bogað, tacnað secgað 21 ðæt hi scylen heora lytle scipu
22 Gerædan to ðære sælade; 23 swa sume ðara synfullan sæton 24 And heora hrycgas ætbrædon, and eft begeoton 25 Swiðor ðonne ðæs ligetes leoma lixe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 E come a l’orlo de l’acqua d’un fosso 26 stanno i ranocchi pur col muso fuori, 27 sì che celano i piedi e l’altro grosso,
28 sì stavan d’ogne parte i peccatori; 29 ma come s’appressava Barbariccia, 30 così si ritraén sotto i bollori.
query.result:
**English:**
25 And as on the edge of a ditch full of water 26 the frogs stand with only their snouts outside, 27 so that they hide their feet and the rest of their bodies,
28 so stood the sinners on every side; 29 but as Barbariccia approached, 30 they drew back beneath the boiling pitch.
**Old English:**
25 And swa swa æt ðæs wæteres brerd ðæs dices 26 ða froxas stodon mid ðæm nosum ute, 27 swa ðæt ða fet and ða oðre lichoman 28 ða synfullan ðær stodon on ælce healfe; 29 ac swa swa Barbariccia nealæhte, 30 ða bugon ða under ða weallende wætan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 I’ sapea già di tutti quanti ’l nome, 38 sì li notai quando fuorono eletti, 39 e poi ch’e’ si chiamaro, attesi come.
query.result:
**English:**
37 He already knew the names of all of them, 38 so I noted them down when they were chosen, 39 and then when they called to each other, I listened attentively.
**Old English:**
37 He ða wiste ðara nama gehwæs, 38 swa ic ða gehyrde ða ðe gecorene wæron, 39 and ða ða hi ða clypedon, ða gehyrde ic hu ða.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 «O Rubicante, fa che tu li metti 41 li unghioni a dosso, sì che tu lo scuoi!», 42 gridavan tutti insieme i maladetti.
query.result:
**English:**
40 "O Rubicante, make sure you set your 41 claws on him, so that you flay him!", 42 all the damned shouted together.
**Old English:**
40 "Eala Rubicanta, wyrc ðæt ðu ða næglas 41 on ðone hrycg sete, swa ðæt ðu hine afylle!", 42 ealle ða awyrgdan togædere clypedon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 E io: «Maestro mio, fa, se tu puoi, 44 che tu sappi chi è lo sciagurato 45 venuto a man de li avversari suoi».
query.result:
**English:**
43 And I: "Master, do, if you are able, 44 so that you may know who is the unfortunate one 45 come into the hands of his adversaries."
**Old English:**
43 And ic: "Laresave, min lareow, gif ðu meaht, 44 ðæt ðu wite hwa ðeos earm is 45 cumen on handa his widerwinna."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Lo duca mio li s’accostò allato; 47 domandollo ond’ ei fosse, e quei rispuose: 48 «I’ fui del regno di Navarra nato.
query.result:
**English:**
46 My guide approached his side; 47 he asked him where he was from, and he replied: 48 "I was born in the kingdom of Navarre.
**Old English:**
46 Min heretoga him ða to sidan eode; 47 he hine ða frignede hwanon he wære, and he ða andswarode: 48 "Ic wæs on Navarra rice geboren.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Mia madre a servo d’un segnor mi puose, 50 che m’avea generato d’un ribaldo, 51 distruggitor di sé e di sue cose.
query.result:
**English:**
49 My mother placed me in service to a lord, 50 who had begotten me from a scoundrel, 51 a destroyer of himself and his possessions.
**Old English:**
49 Min modor me sealde ðeodne to ðeowenne, 50 se ðe me strinde on stæðe unlædan, 51 forwyrd seolfne and his æhta.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Poi fui famiglia del buon re Tebaldo; 53 quivi mi misi a far baratteria, 54 di ch’io rendo ragione in questo caldo».
query.result:
**English:**
52 Then I became a member of the household of the good King Thibault; 53 there I set myself to practicing usury, 54 for which I render an account in this heat.
**Old English:**
52 Þa wæs ic on ðæs gōdan cyninges hired Theobaldus; 53 þær ic me sette to wæfersyne, 54 ðæs ic gesylle rīm on ðisse hætan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 E Cirïatto, a cui di bocca uscia 56 d’ogne parte una sanna come a porco, 57 li fé sentir come l’una sdruscia.
query.result:
**English:**
55 And Ciriatto, from whose mouth issued 56 on every side a tusk like a boar's, 57 made him feel how one of them ripped.
**Old English:**
55 And Ciriatto, fram ðæs muðe com 56 on æghwylce healfe an tusc swylce eofores, 57 dyde hine afandian hu ðæt an slit.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Tra male gatte era venuto ’l sorco; 59 ma Barbariccia il chiuse con le braccia 60 e disse: «State in là, mentr’ io lo ’nforco».
query.result:
**English:**
58 Among evil cats the mouse had come; 59 but Barbariccia seized him with his arms 60 and said: "Stand back while I truss him up."
**Old English:**
58 Betwux þam yflum catum wæs cumen se mus; 59 ac Barbariccia hine bicluse mid his earmum 60 and cwæð: "Standað on bæc, þenden ic hine onforcie."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 E al maestro mio volse la faccia; 62 «Domanda», disse, «ancor, se più disii 63 saper da lui, prima ch’altri ’l disfaccia».
query.result:
**English:**
61 And to my master he turned his face; 62 "Ask him," he said, "again, if more you wish 63 to learn from him, before another undoes him."
**Old English:**
61 And to minum lareowe he wende ða neb; 62 "Ahsa," he cwæð, "gyt, gif ðu mare wilt 63 fram him gehyran, ær he ðone hleor berce."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Lo duca dunque: «Or dì: de li altri rii 65 conosci tu alcun che sia latino 66 sotto la pece?». E quelli: «I’ mi partii,
67 poco è, da un che fu di là vicino.
query.result:
**English:**
64 Then the leader said: "Now tell me, of the other wicked ones, 65 do you know any who are Latin, 66 under the pitch?" And he said: "I departed,
67 a short while ago, from one who was from near there.
**Old English:**
64 Þa cwæð se heretoga: "Nu ðu secge: ðara oðra yfela 65 cnawest ðu ænigne ðe sie Leden 66 under ðære pice?" Þa cwæð he: "Ic me ferde,
67 lyt ðæs, fram anum ðe wæs ðanon neah."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
68 Così foss’ io ancor con lui coperto, 69 ch’i’ non temerei unghia né uncino!».
70 E Libicocco «Troppo avem sofferto», 71 disse; e preseli ’l braccio col runciglio, 72 sì che, stracciando, ne portò un lacerto.
query.result:
**English:**
68 If only I were still hidden with him, 69 for I would fear neither claw nor hook!”
70 And Libicocco said, “We have suffered too much,” 71 and he seized his arm with the pruning hook, 72 so that, tearing it, he carried away a piece of it.
**Old English:**
68 Gif ic wære giet ða gyt mid him behealden, 69 næfre ic ðonne cneo clæm ne nægles!
70 Ða cwæð Libicocco “We habbað to lange þoled,” 71 and feng ða to ðam earme mid ðam bill, 72 and hit ða toslat, and ðær of abræc ðone læssan dæl.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Draghignazzo anco i volle dar di piglio 74 giuso a le gambe; onde ’l decurio loro 75 si volse intorno intorno con mal piglio.
query.result:
**English:**
73 Draghignazzo also wanted to seize him by the legs, 74 down below; whereupon their overseer 75 turned around and around with an evil scowl.
**Old English:**
73 Draca wæs ða gearo ðæt he wolde ðone cniht gefæstnian 74 niðer æt ðam sceancum; ða se heretoga heora 75 bewende hine ymbe and ymbe mid yfelum andwlitan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Quand’ elli un poco rappaciati fuoro, 77 a lui, ch’ancor mirava sua ferita, 78 domandò ’l duca mio sanza dimoro:
79 «Chi fu colui da cui mala partita 80 di’ che facesti per venire a proda?».
query.result:
**English:**
76 When they were somewhat reconciled, 77 my leader asked him, who was still looking at his wound, 78 without delay:
79 "Who was the one from whom you made a bad departure, 80 tell me, in order to come to shore?"
**Old English:**
76 Þa hie sume ða gesib gesibbe wurdon, 77 he hine ða gyt his wunde beheold, 78 min hlaford hine ða sona gefrægn:
79 "Hwa wæs se ðe ðu ðone morðor of gefremede, 80 se ðe ðe brohte to ðisse brime?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
81 Ed ei rispuose: «Fu frate Gomita,
82 quel di Gallura, vasel d’ogne froda, 83 ch’ebbe i nemici di suo donno in mano, 84 e fé sì lor, che ciascun se ne loda.
query.result:
**English:**
81 And he replied: "He was Brother Gomita,
82 from Gallura, a vessel of every fraud, 83 who had his lord's enemies in his power, 84 and dealt with them so that each one praises him.
**Old English:**
81 And he andswarode: "Hit wæs broder Gomita,
82 se ðe wæs of Gallura, wærfæst monna, 83 ðe hæfde his hlafordes widerwinnan on his gewealde, 84 and dyde heom swa ðæt ælc hine herigeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Danar si tolse e lasciolli di piano, 86 sì com’ e’ dice; e ne li altri offici anche 87 barattier fu non picciol, ma sovrano.
query.result:
**English:**
85 He took the money and quietly left, 86 just as he said he would; and in his other offices too 87 he was a barrator, and not just a petty one, but a master.
**Old English:**
85 He nam ða feoh and leolc ða of dune, 86 swa he cwæð; and on oðre æhte eac 87 he wæs swica, noht lyt, ac mæst.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Usa con esso donno Michel Zanche 89 di Logodoro; e a dir di Sardigna 90 le lingue lor non si sentono stanche.
query.result:
**English:**
88 He used to converse with Lord Michel Zanche 89 of Logodoro; and to tell of Sardinia, 90 their tongues did not grow weary.
**Old English:**
88 He hæfde mycelne mægen mid him, 89 and ða leode ðe wæron on Sardinie, 90 ða spræcon ða ilcan spræce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Omè, vedete l’altro che digrigna; 92 i’ direi anche, ma i’ temo ch’ello 93 non s’apparecchi a grattarmi la tigna».
query.result:
**English:**
91 Oh me, see the other one who gnashes his teeth; 92 I would speak of him too, but I fear that he 93 is preparing to scratch my scurf.
**Old English:**
91 Eala me, geseoð ðone oðerne ðe ðær gnornrað; 92 ic wolde eac secgan, ac ic ðæs ondræde 93 ðæt he hine ne gegearwige to gnidan mine hreoflan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 E ’l gran proposto, vòlto a Farfarello 95 che stralunava li occhi per fedire, 96 disse: «Fatti ’n costà, malvagio uccello!».
query.result:
**English:**
94 And the great provost, turning to Farfarello, 95 who rolled his eyes in order to strike, 96 said: "Get out of here, wicked bird!"
**Old English:**
94 And ða mæra provost, gewend to Farfarello, 95 ðe stralede his eagan for to sleân, 96 cwæð: "Far ðe on sidan, yfel fugel!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 «Se voi volete vedere o udire», 98 ricominciò lo spaürato appresso, 99 «Toschi o Lombardi, io ne farò venire;
100 ma stieno i Malebranche un poco in cesso, 101 sì ch’ei non teman de le lor vendette; 102 e io, seggendo in questo loco stesso,
103 per un ch’io son, ne farò venir sette 104 quand’ io suffolerò, com’ è nostro uso 105 di fare allor che fori alcun si mette».

Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Cagnazzo a cotal motto levò ’l muso, 107 crollando ’l capo, e disse: «Odi malizia 108 ch’elli ha pensata per gittarsi giuso!».
query.result:
**English:**
106 Cagnazzo raised his snout at such a speech, 107 shaking his head, and said: "Listen to the malice 108 that he has thought of in order to throw himself down!"
**Old English:**
106 Cagnazzo ða æt ðam worde his nosu up ahof, 107 his heafod cearciende, and ðus cwæð: "Gehyr ðu ða yfelrædene 108 ðe he ðohte ðæt he hine sylfne nyðer awurpe!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Ond’ ei, ch’avea lacciuoli a gran divizia, 110 rispuose: «Malizioso son io troppo, 111 quand’ io procuro a’ mia maggior trestizia».
query.result:
**English:**
109 And he, who had snares in great abundance, 110 replied: "I am too malicious, 111 when I seek my own greater sorrow."
**Old English:**
109 And he, who had snares in great abundance, 110 replied: "I am too malicious, 111 when I seek my own greater sorrow."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Alichin non si tenne e, di rintoppo 113 a li altri, disse a lui: «Se tu ti cali, 114 io non ti verrò dietro di gualoppo,
115 ma batterò sovra la pece l’ali.
query.result:
**English:**
112 Alichino did not hold back, and, running 113 up to the other, said to him: "If you go down, 114 I will not follow you at a gallop,
115 but will beat my wings over the pitch.
**Old English:**
112 Alichin ne heold hine na, and, rynnende 113 to ðæm oðrum, cwæð to him: "Gif ðu ðe astyrest, 114 ic ne cume ðe æfter on galop,
115 ac ic beate ða wyngas ofer ðæm pice.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
116 Lascisi ’l collo, e sia la ripa scudo, 117 a veder se tu sol più di noi vali».
118 O tu che leggi, udirai nuovo ludo: 119 ciascun da l’altra costa li occhi volse, 120 quel prima, ch’a ciò fare era più crudo.
query.result:
**English:**
116 He let go of his neck, and let the bank be his shield, 117 to see if you alone are worth more than us."
118 O you who read, you will hear a new game: 119 each one turned his eyes from the other shore, 120 he first, who was more cruel to do so.
**Old English:**
116 He forlæt ðone sweoran, and ðæt ofer be weall, 117 to geseonne gif ðu ana ðe self bet sy.
118 ðu ðe ðis rædest, ðu gehyrst niwe gamen: 119 æghwylc fram ðære oðre sidan ða eagan awende, 120 se ærra, ðe ðærto wæs ðe heardra.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Lo Navarrese ben suo tempo colse; 122 fermò le piante a terra, e in un punto 123 saltò e dal proposto lor si sciolse.
query.result:
**English:**
121 The Navarrese seized his moment well; 122 he planted his feet on the ground, and in an instant 123 he leaped and freed himself from their plan.
**Old English:**
121 Se ðe Nauarro his tid wel geceas; 122 he sette his fet on ðe grund, and on ane stund 123 he leapede and him from heora ðoht alædde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Di che ciascun di colpa fu compunto, 125 ma quei più che cagion fu del difetto; 126 però si mosse e gridò: «Tu se’ giunto!».
query.result:
**English:**
124 Each of them was remorseful for his fault, 125 but most of all he who was the cause of the error; 126 therefore he moved and cried out: "You have arrived!".
**Old English:**
124 Hwilc ðara ðe for his gylte weop, 125 ac ða swiðost ðe ðæs yfeles wæs fruma; 126 forðæm he hine awehte and clypode: "Þu eart cumen!".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Ma poco i valse: ché l’ali al sospetto 128 non potero avanzar; quelli andò sotto, 129 e quei drizzò volando suso il petto:
130 non altrimenti l’anitra di botto, 131 quando ’l falcon s’appressa, giù s’attuffa, 132 ed ei ritorna sù crucciato e rotto.
query.result:
**English:**
127 But it availed me little: for my wings of suspicion 128 could not outstrip him; he went beneath, 129 and the other, flying, turned his breast upward:
130 not otherwise the duck, when the falcon draws near, 131 suddenly plunges down, 132 and he returns above, vexed and baffled.
**Old English:**
127 Ac me lyt ðuhte: ðæt ða wengan ðæs wenan 128 ne mihte ofercuman; he ðær under geap, 129 and se ða fleagende ofer ðone breost up.
130 Nis ðæs anedes ungelicor, 131 ðonne se hafoc hire nealæceð, ðonne heo ðone grund sohte, 132 and he ðonne on lufte ymbhwyrfeð yrre and gebolgen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Ma l’altro fu bene sparvier grifagno 140 ad artigliar ben lui, e amendue 141 cadder nel mezzo del bogliente stagno.
query.result:
**English:**
139 But the other was indeed a fierce falcon 140 at seizing him well, and both of them 141 fell into the middle of the boiling lake.
**Old English:**
139 Ac se ðeah ðæs grypones gripe wæs 140 ðæt he hine fæste mid his fotum feng, 141 and hine ða on ðone hatan wylm forlæt.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 Lo caldo sghermitor sùbito fue; 143 ma però di levarsi era neente, 144 sì avieno inviscate l’ali sue.
query.result:
**English:**
142 The hot hermit was suddenly up; 143 but he was unable to rise, 144 so entangled were his wings.
**Old English:**
142 Se hlanca anacoreta sona wæs up; 143 ac ðeah hwæðre of ðam stede arisan ne mihte, 144 swa wæron his fyðru beflæmede.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
145 Barbariccia, con li altri suoi dolente, 146 quattro ne fé volar da l’altra costa 147 con tutt’ i raffi, e assai prestamente
148 di qua, di là discesero a la posta; 149 porser li uncini verso li ’mpaniati, 150 ch’eran già cotti dentro da la crosta.
query.result:
**English:**
145 Barbariccia, grieving with his company, 146 made four of them fly from the other bank 147 with all their hooks, and very quickly.
148 From this side and that they descended to their posts; 149 they thrust their hooks toward the ensnared, 150 who were already cooked inside their crusts.
**Old English:**
145 Barbariccia, mid his oðre dolendum, 146 feower he dide fleogan of ðam oðrum sidan 147 mid eallum ðam rafum, and swiðe hraðe.
148 Of ðisum, of ðam oðrum hi nyðer stigon to ðære stede; 149 hi setton ða angelcocas wið ða ymbþanedan, 150 ða wæron ða gecocode innan ðære rindan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
151 E noi lasciammo lor così ’mpacciati.
query.result:
**English:**
151 And we left them thus entangled.
**Old English:**
151 And we læfdon hie ðus forwylmede.
